critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer flash their tail white to warn others of danger nearby.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have excellent night vision, helping them find food in the dark forests they roam.

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can adapt to many environments, from deserts to cities, using clever hunting and communication skills!

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and warmth during cold nights in the wild.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are unique foxes that can climb trees to escape predators or hunt prey.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats can leap over 10 feet horizontally to catch their prey or escape danger!

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines have about 30,000 sharp quills for self-defense, which detach easily when predators get too close!

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers have orange teeth that never stop growing, helping them chew through trees for their dams!

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build lodges from plants and mud, creating cozy homes in wetlands and ponds.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks are semi-aquatic mammals known for their sleek fur and excellent swimming abilities.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers can climb trees to catch prey and escape predators, making them excellent climbers!

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to 8 minutes while hunting for fish!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can find buried nuts even under a foot of snow using smell alone!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their territory, often storing thousands of seeds in their underground caches!

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches that can expand to carry food back to their burrows efficiently!

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally, turning white in winter to blend with snow.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can hop up to 10 feet in a single leap to escape predators!

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have highly sensitive front paws that help them solve puzzles and find food in the dark!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Did you know opossums are immune to snake venom and help control tick populations?

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a smelly liquid up to 10 feet to defend themselves from predators.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide using a special skin flap called a patagium between their legs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to find insects, hunting up to half their body weight each night!

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects, helping control pests naturally at night!

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls hoot with a distinctive "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?" call.

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls have ear tufts that help them blend into tree branches like natural camouflage!

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their food.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where females also sing beautifully to defend territory.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food using spatial memory!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice often use acorns and seeds to store food for winter survival.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most birds that only go upwards!

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers drum on trees to communicate and find insects hidden under bark.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers drum rapidly to communicate and find insects hidden under tree bark.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers can chisel deep rectangular holes in trees to find insects and create nests.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum on trees to communicate and establish territory.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 mph, making them one of North Americaâ€™s fastest birds.

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow in summer to olive in winter.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos change their feather colors slightly based on the season to blend with their environment.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches are one of the few birds with males showing bright red plumage from their diet!

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches have a sweet, raspberry-like song thatâ€™s easy to recognize in North American forests!

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can fly up to 55 miles per hour for short bursts to escape predators!

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create drumming sounds by beating air with their wings to attract mates.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform impressive, synchronized dances to strengthen pair bonds and communicate with each other!

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows are highly intelligent and can recognize human faces to remember friendly or threatening people.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech, showcasing their impressive intelligence and vocal skills!

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks can spot prey from over a mile away using their sharp, powerful eyesight.

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks are skilled hunters, catching birds mid-flight with quick, agile maneuvers through trees.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks can sleep with one eye open to stay alert for predators!

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks are one of the few ducks with colorful, iridescent feathers and bright red eyes!

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada geese mate for life and often stay with their family throughout the year.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for minutes, patiently hunting fish with their sharp, spear-like beaks!

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can live in water temperatures just above freezing, making them amazing cold-weather survivors!

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can snap their jaws shut in less than 0.1 secondsâ€”super fast for catching prey!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill can breathe air using a special organ, helping them survive in low-oxygen waters!

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can grow over 20 inches long and are popular among freshwater anglers nationwide!

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow perch have distinct dark vertical stripes, helping them blend into underwater plants for protection.

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and can strike prey in less than a second underwater!

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched calls signaling early spring.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can grow up to 8 inches long, making them one of North America's largest frogs!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs can be identified by the distinctive ridges running down their backs.

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs have distinctive dark spots that help them blend into grasses and avoid predators.

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and are often found near water hunting frogs and fish.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can hold their breath underwater for up to 30 minutes while hunting fish and amphibians.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes to avoid predators, using similar red, black, and white bands.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles, traveling from North America to Central Mexico each year!

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies use tail-like wing extensions to confuse predators and avoid attacks.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour and have nearly 360-degree vision!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings neatly along their bodies when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies glow using chemical light called bioluminescence to attract mates and communicate in the dark.

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share the location of flowers with their hive mates!

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can buzz pollinate, shaking flowers to release pollen, helping plants like tomatoes grow better!

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers can jump over 20 times their body length using their powerful hind legs!
